Posted: September 6, 2014
												Overlord is just one of those games that I can always come back to. It just makes me smile every time I load it up. It's always satisfying to watch your horde of minions smash things, swarm enemies and gosh darnit, they're just so happy to serve you. It's the most warm and fuzzy game you'll ever play while being a maniacal, all powerful villain. The sequel and spinoffs are good too, but in my opinion? This one will always be the best. The gameplay is solid, the minions are lovable little boogers, it's funny and has endless charm. It's a great game for 5 bucks. And if you can get it on sale? It's an even better deal for hours of gameplay.On another note, I used to own this game for a console, and I personally like the mouse and keyboard setup better. It makes it easier for me to think of The Overlord and the Minions as two seperate entities rather than bunching them together on a controller. But it'll probably come down how you personally prefer it.

Posted: January 19, 2015
												Do you ever wanted to be the bad guy? Do you ever admired the Dark Lord, looking badass, destroying world and killing those pesky heroes? Well, then, this game is for you! Without further delay, lets sink into the fantastic (and sarcastic) world of Overlord!The "bad guy" game market is severelly limited. Everywhere we are feeded with either Goody McGood heroes, fighting to save the world or with shallow concept of being gray and developing our character the way we want to (shallow being either ♥♥♥♥ing rainbows knight in shining armor or baby killing maniac). You wont see that here. Instead, we are evil from the start. And that's what making this game fun.Gameplay is really basic sadly. We are the Overlord. We need to rebuild empire. But Overlord doesn't just go around killing stuff, oh no. He have his minions for that. So we are running around with bunch of our Imps, killing things, collecting stuff to upgrade our tower and (of course) doing some fairly easy puzzles. The style is kinda like Zelda. We need some item or other thing to advance further, we collect it, defeat the boss with that, go to another area, rince and repeat. Graphics are really beatiful. This game aged well, giving nice vibe even so long after the golden release. Locations are colorful and alive yet distinct, there are things moving everywhere, light effects are well made. The olny thing I can really dissaprove of are the overall sugar-like appearances of every single location, but the game have it's (gigantic dose) of humour, and exaggeration pays a big role in that.Music is on par with graphics. Really exaggerated, yet well made and distinct. Sounds are great. Every single detal from random people dialogs to battle sounds are great. Story is great. We are the Overlord, taking over the world yet again. At our path there will be much obstacles, including corrupted heroes, lack of resources and other natural or unnatural calamities. Narration is smooth and plot twists are well done. We even have the pleasure of having a wife here, and Overlord is not your average multihour RPG.Bad things? Well, for starters all our work is done by minions. I won't say its technically bad, but our Overlord can't do crap. Its kind of stupid, we are the antihero of this world. The other thing, because the game is strongly influenced by Zelda franchise, we can't really talk about open world RPG or exploration all that much. Oh, we can go to the previous locations to loot additional stuff with our new powers (it's unattainable otherwise, the easiest example would be Imp Pillars in the water, we can't get them, until we get Blue Imps), but we need to go from point A to B on a series of semi-linear locations in order to progress with the story. Also our Overlord can't be developed all that much. More minions, stronger armor and weapon and minion types. Sadly that's all. Well, if you we're spending all nights in Dungeon Keeper, this game is for you. It have great sense of humor (and a bit of self awareness), nice graphics, enjoyable and easy gameplay, and, of course, you play as the bad guy. Its a good piece, althou technically not a RPG, and sadly, kind of short. But hey, its Zelda on crack, so it can't be all that bad! I would recommend this game to anyone from new to experienced players. Go! Conquer the world, Overlord!Zawisza out.

												Wonderfully fun game, set in a humorous fantasy world where you are the "bad" guy. Posted: August 12, 2012
												Overlord is the third game in the Dungeon Keeper trilogy. After conquering the underground of Eversmile, the dark conqueror decides to take his reign once step further, to the overworld. Armed with minions of different flavors, the Overlord must stop the fat hobbit to ensure the world is engulfed in shadow. Often called Pikmin in Hell, Overlord lets you control one powerful dark lord of the Sith. With War's Gauntlet, Melkor can call upon his minions to do mischevious deeds, like drinking beer, breaking stuff, killing sheep, killing peasants, throwing fire at people, reviving their own kind and even peeing. The main draw to this game is hats. As you kill different bosses, your minions can obtain a special weapon or hat based on the enemy you killed. It doesn't matter though because those minions will probably die later on anyway and you'll lose your♥♥♥♥♥♥Overlord is a cruel and demeaning game. I rate it one scythe out of death.

Posted: March 2, 2015
												Overlord is a game I want to like but that I fail to. The premise is sound: you are an evil Overlord who commands an army of minions and seeks to do evil deeds across an otherwise rather peaceful land. Which could be fun, if the game didn't get in the way. To rebind the keyboard controls you have to open up a seperate configuration window that has drop-down menus as opposed to the standard 'click-and-select' method most games use. On top of that the key-binds only appear to take some of the time. Now if you're like me and own a controller you might think yourself smart in using it, except that the controller controls are just as bad. The right-analog stick doesn't turn the camera and thus you're left to the mercy of when the game deicides you need to turn. The minion controls work reasonably well but I found it very removed and it felt more like an RTS with a third-person camera. The game is awfully vague at times as well and you'll find yourself without an idea of what you're supposed to be doing, how to go about doing it or what your overall goal is.

Posted: March 1, 2015
												Overlord is one of those games where its easy to promote to under 16s yet difficult to push towards the older age groups.This jovel offering provides the player with an opportunity to amass and control an army to carryout a set of destructive whims in the rise for total domination. Your afforded 4 types of minions to control independantly or all together, each with the specialised traits along with the opportunity to up your skill level improving all facets from minion to overlord and even includes the chance to decorate ones own evil castle.Sadly as pleasant as it may be it doesnt come without issues like control of minions in certain circumstances, poor camera control, sticking animation and no guide to know where the new areas are.All in all recommended in a sale but really only of interest to the quite young as not challenging near enough i feel to keep most 16s and up engaged what with no skill setting being available.

												For a fan of any game; with it's dark humour, reasonable storyline and tactical combat, there's everything you could hope to find in a game. Truly, one of the greatest ever. 												That was great! Pikmin in the style of Fable plus Dungeon Keeper. What's not to like? Well, you could nitpit and say that there's no minimap, plus the tutorialization is broken in a couple of key places (how to sweep and how to use guard markers). And there's no Run speed, so you're going to be doing a lot of trogging around. But your minions are SO MUCH FUN. You won't feel so much evil as much-loved in this game. 												It's like Pikmin if Olimar could actually contribute in fights. You're evil, and so are your minions, so you don't feel bad when your minions die, and the gameplay tends more toward the dungeon aspect than the overworld part, with conquest being your main goal and treasure a side bonus, rather than the other way around.Also you have an overlord base and it's amazing.Minions are somehow adorable and hideous at the same time, it's creepy.Controls can be a bit clunky at times, but you only really notice it when your minion squad keeps running into walls when you're trying to make them pick up their weapon bonuses.

Posted: December 5, 2011
												This was the first game I played when I got my new graphics card.And wow was Im pleased with my choice.Take control of, The Overlord.Build your castle, train your minions, forge armour and weapons and then march out into the peaceful world full of butterflies and bleating sheep, and MURDER THEM ALL!!! ... Or you can be boring a be a Good guy, people will praise you, but being bad, they will bow at your feet. Depending on if your Nice or Nasty you gain different items.Customize your overlord with armour and weapons of your choice.Customize your castle, the colours, statues, bowls of fire and spiked spires.The game world is big. Not Elder Scrolls BIG but still, big enough. Colourful nice area's, dark and dank, fire and brimstone, bones and sand. There's a good variety.The humour is what makes this game. Minions will drink beer, then pee on the tables. Sing songs, say fun lines like "Loook Sheepies!" while they viciously attack and slaughter them all.Buy it. Play it.9 / 10

Posted: December 27, 2011
												To be honest, I bought the Overlord bundle on a whim during the Halloween sale.Now, I'd say it's the best $5 I've spent on a Steam game to date - the game itself is fairly straightforward, but not so easy as to feel like a waste of time. The controls are pretty good with a bit of tweaking, and the graphics, while nowhere near the level of Skyrim, look good for most aspects. The quirky humor thrown in is often rather entertaining.The main downside for me would be the controls. If using an adapter and (I assume) non-360 controller, the defaults are awkward and incomplete. The game also doesn't explain a few functions, making some abilities a bit challenging to find - particularly, actively repositioning the stationary "guard marker" to move your goblins around; I thought it was stuck where it was set for most of the game.

												Fun concept and game, and the best part of the game is listening to the various comments your minions utter as they pillage, kill and cause mayhem, or as they fetch items for you or as you sacrifice them, he he he. It does get a tad repetitive after awhile though despite learning to control an increasingly diverse stable (hah!) of minions with different abilities which are necessary to solve increasingly complex (relatively so) puzzles as you progress through the game. The same can be said of the combat in that the Overlord himself has an extremely limited range of abilities and moves and you have to rely more on your minions to combat your foes, some of which can be quite tricky and require a good balance of minion types and careful management.I didn't finish the game due to its repetitive nature but it's fun enough that I may go back and finish it at some point.7/10

Posted: August 12, 2012
												Overlord is the third game in the Dungeon Keeper trilogy. After conquering the underground of Eversmile, the dark conqueror decides to take his reign once step further, to the overworld. Armed with minions of different flavors, the Overlord must stop the fat hobbit to ensure the world is engulfed in shadow. Often called Pikmin in Hell, Overlord lets you control one powerful dark lord of the Sith. With War's Gauntlet, Melkor can call upon his minions to do mischevious deeds, like drinking beer, breaking stuff, killing sheep, killing peasants, throwing fire at people, reviving their own kind and even peeing. The main draw to this game is hats. As you kill different bosses, your minions can obtain a special weapon or hat based on the enemy you killed. It doesn't matter though because those minions will probably die later on anyway and you'll lose your♥♥♥♥♥♥Overlord is a cruel and demeaning game. I rate it one scythe out of death.

There was no penalty for not going full good/evil, just a sequence of yes/no's that affected your gameplay and decided your ending cutscenes. Story blew me completely away that I had to wiki it after.There is a cute and dark humour style closely resembling the first Fable game.I'm not surprised there is a cult fandom because they emerge around games, (warts and all.) The goblins are adorable, yet your only incentive to preserve them is to sacrifice them for better armor/weapon enchantments. It's so weird that so many fans of this game would get so attached to their digital r♥♥♥♥♥♥♥that the function of specifically tagging and bringing them to life was made available in Overlord 2.

												This is a funny RPG style game.  It's compared often to Fable because you can choose to be good or evil, however I believe the game is designed to be evil specifically.  I found the game to be challenging and entertaining, played it all the way through at least once.  It is linear so replayability suffers, but it was still a fun game.The controls are fairly easy to use, though sometimes it can be a little frustrating if they don't move exactly right.  There's no micromanaging required, the minions pick up things by themselves and show it off as they run around.  Graphics are good, sound is good.  Tons of sarcasm in this game, which I especially like.

Posted: January 24, 2015
												Overlord is one of the best games I've ever played! The game is so fun because not only do you feel powerful. but you feel unstoppable! The game has tons of quests! It took me five hours to complete all the quests in  the first area. You can choose to be an evil force to be reckoned or a heroic force to be reckoned with. You can even customize your tower! How freaking cool is that! It's a pretty funny game as well. You can beat the crap out of your court jester, feed your minions and watch them pee after they finish their food and drink, slaughter hobbit-like creatures called halflings and their morbily obese king, and a whole lot more. The game is kind of linear but the areas are pretty big. I say they're linear because usually the way of traveling around are pathways that connect in someway.  Still it doesn't bother me because there is a lot to explore. Now, about forging. Whenever you forge and item whether it be weapons or armor, you have to use minions to do so. The more minions you use the more powerful the item you are making or upgrading will become.Minions come in four types. Brown, red, green, and blue. Brown are your standard minions. They are just mainly used for fighting. Red are invunrable to fire. Green are invunrable to poisonous fumes, and blue can enter water. I highly recommend this game!

												8 / 10 - Action Funny 3rd Person Mastermind Controller Game:What can I say other than "Kill the Innocent Forest Critters!" just doesn't do this game justice.Pro's:+++/Playing an evil character against good enemies that seem to stem a greater evil than anything you could conceivable do in the game to make up for their evil goodness.++/Sound and Audio is a good combination of music that makes you giggling and wanting to thrash and thomp around eagerly.+/Controls are a bit wonky but understandable given the development timeline of when it was released and under what guise.++/Minion Mastery, if you like Necromancers, Summoners, Conjurers, and Coercers you'll love this, the ability to have your minions thrash at everything while you calmly read a passage from a book of poems makes the epicness just that much greater (PS: you can't obviously sit and read in the game, but you can from your RL chair).Cons:-/Not much diversity to one game to another, so replayability mostly in the guise of just wantent, Sociapathic destruction of people, livestock, and well the baying of sheep as your minions ride and crack at them.--/No Quicksave, you die, thats right you go back to the Auto-Save the game decides where you should start from.All and all, a fair good game that makes you laugh, gives you a jolly good time of fun and♥♥♥♥♥♥kicking without the emptiness feeling that accompanies. Besides, at least you get can get your minions drunk, slaughter a village, and claim Minion Drunken Mindless Manslaughter was the result.

Posted: March 25, 2016
												"For the Overlorrrd!"This game is an absolute gem. A game where you take on the role of an evil overlord commanding a group of less-than-civil goblins, this game combines interesting story, solid gameplay, and strategy with a taste of laughing gas. It's hard to take anything seriously in this game when your goblin minions are more intent on being silly and disruptive than killing (unless you command them, of course-they always listen to their eeevil Overlord), especially when there's an entire mechanic around booting your minions to the ground. Seriously, those goblins are so adorable, it's actually heartbreaking when one that's been with you on many adventures falls dead. Which happens often.This really is a feel-good game. It's always good for a laugh and brightening your day... although it may be a bit rough jumping back into the middle of it if you take a long hiatus.

												Old, sometimes frustrating if you don't know what you are doing but veryfunny if you like some dark humor.Overlord 2 is much better, but this game is a rough gem as far as I'm concerned and a great part one in the series.It still looks quite good and plays well as long as you use a gamepad, preferrably one with the xbox button layout or with a programmable layout so you can match the Minions to the correct buttons on the pad.The minions are a great idea, making for some unique ways of solving the in game quests.They can fight for you, throw levers, get trough narrow gaps to attack an enemy from behind and be used as traps to ambush the enemies you just lured to them with some other minions.If you get adept at controlling them your dark lord will often never need to lift a gauntleted finger to defeat a lot of the foes in the game. And they are just so incredibly enthousiastic at sacrificing themselves for you that you just have to smile (In an evil way of course).You will even use them to create better armor and weapons for your lord by throing them directly in the furnace in your forge.The game world is a nice "classical fantasy gone wrong" wher you finally get to play as absolute evil, or just slightly evil if you prefer. Both have their up and down side.True, hearing "For YOUUUUU!" a lot can get a bit annoying at times, but that is a common problem with soundbytes in games isn't it.If you can get it with the expansion pack, do so because it contains a few of the most excellent levels in the game and leads to the events of Overlord 2.

Posted: December 16, 2015
8/10Very nice little game with a lot of humor along the side.You are the evil Overlord laying death and destruction to everyone and everything standing in your way. The minions, backbone of your combat strenght, are loyal tools expecting to be used as you please and their soul purpose is for you to reach your goals. The game does a brilliant job in showing of how disposable your minions are to you throughout the entire game.Overlord offers intuitive controls that are easy to manage once you got used to them. The game provides you with fun little puzzles and challenges forming the core of your gaming experience.The variation of minions is well handled, their strenghts and weaknesses balanced and how you use them is up to you.Each minion type (four in total) provides a different bonus you need to progress. Like just red minions can walk through flames while blue minions are the only ones that can swim...and so on. Puzzles usually require you to have a good mix of all your minions.The game itself takes your hand at the start showing and explaining all basics which you can build your own tactics upon later.Cons are:The upgrade system would need some improvement to it and the game ultimately falls a little short. Enemy A.I. is easily outsmarted by common knowledge sadly making some bossfights way to easy.
